channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Europe’s Economic Laggards Have Become Its Leaders
item.description: More than a decade after painful austerity, Greece, Portugal and Spain have been growing faster than traditional powerhouses like Germany.

item.title: London Sword Attack Leaves Several Injured, Police Say
item.description: Five people were hospitalized after the stabbing, and a suspect was arrested. Video of the incident showed a man wielding a large sword near several houses.

item.title: An $850 million retail giant is giving candidates their questions before a job interview
item.description: Even those applying for senior roles at John Lewis Partnership will be able to peak at the interview questions in advance

item.title: Inside a Navy Submarine Navigating the Arctic
item.description: A Times photojournalist embarked on a nuclear-powered attack sub to see how the Pentagon is training for a potential war below the frozen sea.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: U.N. Court to Issue Decision on Arms Sales to Israel
item.description: The International Court of Justice in The Hague will decide on whether countries supplying arms are liable for how they are used.

item.title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang’s staff say he is a demanding perfectionist who’s not easy to work for—and he agrees
item.description: "It's the most extraordinary thing, that a normal dishwasher busboy could grow up to be this."

item.title: The Secret Push That Could Ban TikTok
item.description: U.S. lawmakers have long worried that the Chinese government could use the app to spread propaganda.

item.title: Blinken Arrives in Jordan to Discuss Aid for Gaza
item.description: The visit comes as the Biden administration is trying to increase pressure on Hamas to accept a deal that would result in a temporary cease-fire in the war in Gaza and the release of some hostages.

item.title: Samsung joins Nvidia in AI semiconductor boom as memory chip sales help profits quadruple last year’s result
item.description: The results underscore how demand for the memory chips that power modern electronics and artificial intelligence is starting to rebound after a severe downturn.

item.title: Columbia Protesters Occupy Building, and Trump Complains About His Lawyer
item.description: Plus, a deadly day for law enforcement.

item.title: Europe’s Economic Laggards Have Become Its Leaders
item.description: More than a decade after painful austerity, Greece, Portugal and Spain have been growing faster than traditional powerhouses like Germany.

item.title: Geopolitics and U.S. rules push chip firms to decouple from mainland China, with one major Taiwanese testing company ditching the market entirely
item.description: On Friday, King Yuan Electronics Co., a Taiwan-based chip testing firm, announced that it was selling its mainland China-based operations, citing geopolitics.

item.title: Police Shooting in Charlotte Kills 4 Officers: What to Know
item.description: A police officer and three members of a U.S. Marshals task force were fatally shot while serving warrants to a suspect, who was also killed.

item.title: Edward Dwight, Once Picked to Be the First Black Astronaut in Space, Aims for Orbit at Last
item.description: Six decades ago, Mr. Dwight’s shot at becoming the first Black astronaut in space was thwarted by racism and politics. Now, at 90, he’s finally going up.

item.title: Satya Nadella says Microsoft will pump $1.7bn into Indonesia for AI and cloud projects as Big Tech floods into Southeast Asia
item.description: “The intelligence revolution is going to be the next major bend in the curve of GDP growth,” Nadella told hundreds of attendees at a company event in Jakarta.
